page.title: 12LOCAL HISTORY
page.content: This is an area, sparsely occupied now, whose roots go far back into time. At Harlyn in 1900 AD. was re- vealed an Iron Age burial ground of approx. 130 graves, with many skelet_ ons in crouched position. Brooches and other grave goods are now in the R.I. of Cornwall Museum at Truro - as are Bronze Age relics from Harlyn Farm. Countless ships have become wrecks in the area around Trevose Head. Two may still be seen. At Harlyn Bay, by the stream bridge, lie the remains of 'The Industry', a wooden brigantine. At Booby's Bay, the keel, frames, part decking, funnel, capstan, anchor, etc. of the 20,000 ton steel vessel 'Carl' of Hamburg, still lie. During the winter of l985, what remains of this ship were uncovered by the sea, but most now lies beneath the sand.
